p: The phytochemical occurrence in peppermint leaves and oil depends on plant maturity, variety, geographical origin, and processing methods' conditions [ 304– 307]. As fatty acids, there have been found palmitic, linoleic, and linolenic acids [ 308]. The main components identified in the volatile oil of peppermint are menthol (33–60%), menthone (15–32%), isomenthone (2–8%), 1,8-cineole (eucalyptol) (5–13%), menthyl acetate (2–11%), menthofuran (1–10%), limonene (1–7%), β-myrcene (0.1–1.7%), β-caryophyllene (2–4%), pulegone (0.5–1.6%), and carvone (1%) [ 304, 309]. The fresh leaves contain 1.2–3.9% (v/w) of essential oil, while the dried leaves is reported to contain only 21% of the original oil [ 310].
